descriptions.title: Alchemical Ritual
descriptions.content:
Description

Literally "extracting the essence," these types of rituals have as their goal the extraction of the potency or "essence" (bcud) from substances (such as flowers, mercury, the elements, and so forth), generally with the goal of using that substance for nourishment, to increase one's lifespan, or to strengthen one's body. Such practices are especially popular with hermits who have only limited access to ordinary food.

The category of "alchemy" is very broad, and can refer to practices that simply transform substances (such as transforming iron into gold); in addition, it can refer to practices where a yogi subsists on extracted esences, and to sexual practices that involve extracting energetic potencies from a consort.

Note that it remains to be seen how "ritualistic" alchemy is. Much of the literature devoted to "extracting the essence" is undoubtedly more instructional than ritual in nature.

Example Texts

  • bcud len gyi gdams pa rim pa lnga
  • bcud len gyi cha lag rin chen za ma tog
  • bcud len sgrub thabs
  • bcud len rgyas bshad zag med bde gter (by De’u dmar dge bshes Btsan ‘dzin phun tshogs)
  • See also TBRC topic bcud len

Secondary Sources

White, David Gordon. The Alchemical Body: Siddha Traditions in Medieval India. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1996.
